[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/7372762/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/7372762)

Coverage increased (+0.3%) to 46.86% when pulling **52a1506162dec4b5b87fe30d5f11b81beaa582ca on autumnust:fsjobcatalog** into **1dc980eec5969f4dfd75b808e5913c135c10538f on linkedin:master**.
@ydai1124 addressed all comments please take another look.

Since a lot of changes have accumulated, I'll re-summarize the changes:

Changes to the new API:
- GobblinInstanceLauncher/GobblinInstanceDriver
  - Renamed GobblinInstanceLauncher.getName() to GobblinInstanceLauncher.getInstanceName()
  - Made GobblinInstanceLauncher extend configurable since it is responsible of holding the system configuration
- JobCatalog/JobSpec:
  - Refactored the register/unregister methods into a separate interface - JobCatalogListenersContainer
  - Reworked JobSpec.Builder to be convention-based and be able to reuse some of the properties in the Job configuration
-  JobExecutionLauncher/JobExecutionDriver
  - Added the class JobExecutionDriver to control/monitor the execution of a single gobblin job
  - JobExecutionLauncher is not a factory for JobExecutionDriver instances
  - Add JobExecutionStateListenerContainer interface for managing JobExecutionStateListener instances
- JobExecutionStatus/JobExecutionState
  - JobExecutionStatus is now an interface
  - JobExecutionState is now responsible for the state management (including callbacks)

Implementations:
- Added a sample implementation JobLauncherExecutionDriver of JobExecutionDriver which acts as an adapter to the legacy JobLauncher/JobLauncherFactory API
- Added DefaultGobblinInstanceDriverImpl which accepts all components but it is not responsible for managing them. This implementation can be used as a shell to implement a typical Gobblin job lifecycle
- Added StandardGobblinInstanceDriver which will be responsible for instantiating and managing the instance components and passing them to DefaultGobblinInstanceDriverImpl
- Added StandardGobblinInstanceLauncher-- a very rudimentary implementation to instantiate StandardGobblinInstanceDriver
- Standard implementations for JobCatalogListenersContainer (JobCatalogListenersList) and JobExecutionStateListenerContainer (JobExecutionStateListeners)
- The above use a generic callback infrastructure in gobblin-utility/gobblin/util/callbacks
  - Callbacks a typically represented through a Function<L, R> where L is the listener type and R is the callback result (or Void)
  - There is a helper class Callback<L, R> to let adding some human-readable description of the callback
  - Callbacks are created by a CallbackFactory which is responsble for binding any parameters that need to be passed to the callback
  - Callbacks are managed by CallbacksDispatcher

Changes to legacy code:
- Documentation and helper methods in JobState to decrease reliance on direct access to job properties
- Added a description of current state diagram for RunningState based on code inspection
- Helper methods in JobContext
- Added a method JobLauncherFactory. newJobLauncher() method to allow instantiating a specific JobLauncher type instead of relying on the job config

As discussed, there some follow-up items:
- Have an internal implementation of JobExecutionStatus in JobExecutionState that can be easily serialized/deserialized
- Add more javadocs to CallbacksDispatcher to explain usage

I'll make the above in a separate PR since my local copy is already ahead of this PR and I'd rather don't merge any more changes in this PR.

Looks good in general.

Please switch the order of sections a bit, that way people don't have to read implementation in order to use templates.
1. How to use template (include here the example with `wikipedia.pull`, just the short file)
2. Available templates. Also, for each one please include a short description and required options.
3. How to create your own template (in here include the actual `wikiSample.template`)
4. How does template work in Gobblin

Also, you should have a page on how to use pull files in HDFS (e.g. what system property needs to be set, etc.)
@ydai1124 Thanks for the review. I've addressed PR comments and will be working on merging it from master branch's latest code.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/7515808/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/7515808)

Coverage increased (+0.005%) to 46.662% when pulling **2f03a5aa0f67e195b3c55b4343c5b2a091269116 on pcadabam:master** into **13a37da4d404ecd906368434aac0cab5e944c8b3 on linkedin:master**.

I think there must have been some misunderstanding with respect to the watermarker factory. Right now the implementation uses a public API (the fact that you need a constructor that takes state to instantiate a HiveSourceWatermarker implementation) that is undocumented and only visible in an obscure code location.

What  I mean was:
a) Keep the HiveSourceWatermarkerFactory interface. 
b) Have at least two implementations PartitionLevelWatermarker.Factory and TableLevelWatermarker.Factory 
c) Have HIVE_SOURCE_WATERMARKER_FACTORY_KEY instead of HIVE_SOURCE_WATERMARKER_CLASS_KEY
d) Always instantiate the factory class from HIVE_SOURCE_WATERMARKER_FACTORY_KEY using the default constructor.
e) Invoke createFromState() on the above instance.

I would even suggest that we go as far as not having the constructor for PartitionLevelWatermarker and TableLevelWatermarker take a state in the constructor but only the parts of the sate that they need. It should be the factory which adapts from the passed state to whatever is needed for the construction of  PartitionLevelWatermarker and TableLevelWatermarker.

Right now the code is full of these opaque reflection invocations and passing of state which is a glorified map. This completely obfuscates what is used where and we keep having this unintended consequence when changing something in the state.

If we want to program in Python, we should program in Python, not abuse Java :-)
